Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South10th FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2630tamiment.wagner@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2019-08-15T15:09:19Finding aid written in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Julius Wiesenfeld Papers
Wiesenfeld, Julius
WAG.348
1.75 linear feet in 3 manuscript boxes and 1 half manuscript box
1941-1977 Julius "Julie" Wiesenfeld (1913-1979) was a professor of mathematics and union and civil rights advocate. While in Cedar Falls, Wiesenfeld served as the President of the Black Hawk County Union Council, and was active in union, civil rights, and anti-war organizing, helping to organize the UNI chapter of the American Federation of Teachers, and adovcating for amnesty of Vietnam draft resistance while he was a delegate to the State Democratic Convention in 1968 and 1972. The Julius Wiesenfeld Papers (dated approximately 1941-1977) consist of correspondence, writings, and newspaper clippings on a variety of topics related to the Old Left, including labor strikes, union organizing, conflict within the Socialist Labor Party of America, voting rights and voting registration efforts in the 1960s, opposition to American involvement in Vietnam, Marxist theory and history, and international Marxism during the mid-20th century, including the student-led Red Guards in China and de-Stalinisation in the Soviet Union. Materials are in English. Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.
Scope and Contents
The Julius Wiesenfeld Papers (dated approximately 1941-1977) consist of correspondence, writings, and newspaper clippings on a variety of topics related to the Old Left, including labor strikes, union organizing, conflict within the Socialist Labor Party of America, voting rights and voting registration efforts in the 1960s, the American Veterans Committee and opposition to American involvement in Vietnam, Marxist theory and history, and international Marxism during the mid-20th century, including the student-led Red Guards in China and de-Stalinisation in the Soviet Union. The bulk of the correspondence in this collection is between Wiesenfeld and Abe Levine, the first United Teachers Federation Vice President for elementary schools.
Biographical Note
Julius "Julie" Wiesenfeld (1913-1979) was a professor of mathematics and union and civil rights advocate. Wiesenfeld was born in New York City. Herved in the United States Army during World War II, worked for the Republic Steel Corporation from 1946-1951, taught at the Harvard School for Boys of the University of Chicago from 1957-1963. Wiesenfeld earned his B.S. from Roosevelt University in Chicago (1953) and his M.S. from the University of Chicago (1957). In 1963 he joined the mathematics faculty of the University of Northern Iowa (then known as the State College of Iowa). While in Cedar Falls, Wiesenfeld served as the President of the Black Hawk County Union Council, and was active in union, civil rights, and anti-war organizing, helping to organize the UNI chapter of the American Federation of Teachers, and adovcating for amnesty of Vietnam draft resistance while he was a delegate to the State Democratic Convention in 1968 and 1972.
Source:
Rod Library, University of Northern Iowa. "Julius Wiesenfled." https://library.uni.edu/collections/special-collections/biographical-sketches/julius-wiesenfeld (retrieved August 15, 2019).
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Conditions Governing Use
Tamiment Library has no information about copyright ownership for this collection and is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from it. Materials in this collection, which were created in 1941-1976 range, are expected to enter the public domain in 2061.
Arrangement
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
There is no documentation concerning the provenance of this collection.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Julius Wiesenfeld Papers; WAG 348; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Processing Information
At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders and described on the collection-level.
